snippet: Americans overwhelmingly favor cameras in public, judging privacy curbs an acceptable price for greater security from terrorist attacks, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll finds that Americans overwhelmingly favor installing video surveillance cameras in public places, seeing infringement of privacy as acceptable trade-off for greater security from terrorist attacks.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and DALIA SUSSMAN
byline.contributor: Mark Landler reported from Washington, and Dalia Sussman from New York. Megan Thee-Brenan, Allison Kopicki and Marina Stefan contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Americans overwhelmingly favor cameras in public, judging privacy curbs an acceptable price for greater security from terrorist attacks, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline.main: Poll Finds Strong Acceptance for Public Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Poll Finds Strong Support for Surveillance Cameras
